title: Conserving America
speaker: Matthew Spalding
description: Matthew Spalding, a vice president at Hillsdale College, sets out the landscape for the Presidential Administration Academy by talking about common conservative principles.

title: The History of the Conservative Movement
speaker: Christopher Malagisi
description: Christopher Malagisi, the executive director of outreach for Hillsdale College's Washington, D.C., campus, gives a history that spans from the early-20th century Progressive Era to the 1964 defeat of Barry Goldwater and the “Reagan revolution.”

title: Why Your Service Matters: How Presidential Appointees at All Levels Impact Policy
speaker: Multiple Speakers
description: Three Heritage Foundation experts discuss the role that political appointees play in making policy.

title: Political Appointees & The Federal Workforce
speaker: Spencer Chretien
description: Spencer Chretien discusses the critical role that he says political appointees play in carrying out the vision of a conservative administration.

title: Presidential Transitions & Appointee Hiring: What You Need To Know
speaker: Ed Corrigan and Rick Dearborn
description: Ed Corrigan and Rick Dearborn outline how an aspiring political appointee can get a foot in the door during a presidential transition.

title: Deep Dive on The Federal Background Investigation & Security Clearance Process
speaker: James Sherk
description: James Sherk gives an overview of the federal government's background check process, including what disqualifies an individual, like substance abuse issues, and what does not.

title: The Political Appointee's Survival Guide
speaker: Bethany Kozma and Others
description: Bethany Kozma, who was the deputy chief of staff at the U.S. Agency for International Development during the Trump administration, talks with six other former Trump administration staffers about what it's like to serve as a political appointee in the federal government.

title: Time Management for Political Appointees
speaker: Katie Sullivan
description: Katie Sullivan explains how political appointees can maximize their time in government by vetting whom they meet with and not allowing career civil servants to fill their calendar with meetings.

title: The Art of Professionalism
speaker: Chris Hayes and Karoline Leavitt
description: Chris Hayes and Karoline Leavitt discuss tenets of how to act with professionalism while serving in government.

title: How to Staff Your Principal
speaker: Jeff Small
description: Jeff Small discusses the day-to-day work of serving closely with a senior government official like a cabinet secretary.

title: Hidden Meanings: The Monsters in the Attic
speaker: Katie Sullivan and Bethany Kozma
description: Katie Sullivan and Bethany Kozma discuss supposed `left`-wing code words and biased language that future appointees should be aware of and root out.

title: How to Work With the Media
speaker: Alexei Woltornist
description: Alexei Woltornist talks about how political appointees should navigate the modern media environment, including bypassing mainstream news sources and focusing on conservative outlets because those are the only ones conservative voters trust.

title: Oversight & Investigations
speaker: Mike Howell, Tom Jones, and Michael Ding
description: Mike Howell, Tom Jones and Michael Ding explain what government oversight entails, the ins and outs of public-records laws and how political appointees should think about when and when not to put sensitive communications in writing.

title: The Federal Budget Process
speaker: Michael Duffey
description: Michael Duffey explains key budgetary policies, such as the difference between appropriations and authorization bills and discretionary versus mandatory spending.

title: The Administrative State: What it is & How to Address the Problem
speaker: Paul Ray
description: Paul Ray explains what the so-called administrative state does and how a conservative administration could use its authority to rein in government regulation.

title: How to Promulgate a Rule
speaker: David Burton
description: David Burton discusses how the federal government's regulatory process works and the role of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs.

title: Taking the Reins: How Conservatives Can Win the Regulations Game
speaker: Roger Severino
description: Roger Severino talks about what lessons conservatives learned about passing new rules during the Trump presidency and how to be more effective in a future conservative administration.

title: Executive Order Drafting & Implementation
speaker: Steven G. Bradbury
description: Steven G. Bradbury explains the process of writing and carrying out executive orders, drawing on experience from the Trump presidency.

title: Advancing the President's Agenda as a Political Executive
speaker: Donald J. Devine and James Bacon
description: Donald J. Devine and James Bacon discuss different strategies for promoting the president's policies as a high-ranking political appointee.

title: How to Get Your Policy Through the Agency
speaker: Dan Huff
description: Dan Huff talks about how to navigate the policymaking process in the executive branch.

title: Congressional Relations: How to work with Members
speaker: Hugh Fike and James Braid
description: Hugh Fike and James Braid talk about what executive branch political appointees should know and expect about working with congressional offices and elected officials.

title: Building Winning Coalitions to Advance Policy
speaker: Paul Teller and Sarah Makin
description: Paul Teller and Sarah Makin discuss what strategies political appointees can use to work with pro-life, gun-rights and other outside advocacy groups to pass policies.

title: Best Practices in Social Media to Advance Policy
speaker: Ben Friedmann
description: Ben Friedmann explains how political appointees can most effectively use social media to promote conservative policies and messages.
